statement.text: The Planck frequency (ν_P) is the frequency corresponding to a photon with Planck energy, representing the highest meaningful frequency in physics. It equals the inverse of the Planck time, setting the natural unit for oscillation frequency in quantum gravity. At this frequency, each photon cycle occurs in one Planck time.

explanation.intuition: The Planck frequency is how fast something could oscillate at the fundamental quantum gravity scale. At ν_P ≈ 1.85 × 10⁴³ Hz, each cycle takes only one Planck time (~10⁻⁴⁴ s). This is inconceivably fast - compare to visible light at ~10¹⁴ Hz or the fastest nuclear transitions at ~10²⁰ Hz. The Planck frequency is 10²³× higher than anything we've observed!
explanation.key_insight: The Planck frequency has deep connections to quantum mechanics through E = hν. A photon with Planck frequency would have Planck energy: E = hν_P = h/t_P = E_P. Such a photon would be an immediate black hole! This is why ν_P represents the maximum meaningful frequency - higher frequencies would create black holes larger than their wavelength.
explanation.technical_details: Planck frequency ν_P = 1/t_P = √(c⁵/ℏG) = 1.8549(21) × 10⁴³ Hz. Angular frequency: ω_P = 2π·ν_P = 1.1656(13) × 10⁴⁴ rad/s. Energy relation: E_P = h·ν_P = ℏ·ω_P. Wavelength of Planck-frequency photon: λ = c/ν_P = c·t_P = ℓ_P (Planck length). Uncertainty from G dominates: δν_P/ν_P ~ 1.1 × 10⁻⁵.
common_misconceptions: Planck frequency is the 'minimum' frequency - FALSE: it's a MAXIMUM (corresponds to maximum energy photon)
Photons with ν > ν_P exist - FALSE: such photons would be black holes
This frequency is observed - FALSE: highest observed frequencies are ~10²³× lower
ν_P is a minimum for some quantum process - FALSE: frequencies can be arbitrarily low

definitions_glossary.planck_frequency: ν_P = 1/t_P ≈ 1.85 × 10⁴³ Hz, the maximum meaningful frequency

definition.@value: The frequency corresponding to a photon of Planck energy, ν_P = 1/t_P ≈ 1.85 × 10⁴³ Hz, representing the maximum meaningful oscillation frequency in physics

learning_objectives: Calculate Planck frequency from Planck time
Understand E = hν connection to Planck energy
Recognize Planck frequency as maximum meaningful frequency
common_errors: Thinking ν_P is a minimum (it's a maximum)
Missing that ν > ν_P photons would be black holes
physics_insights: Photon at ν_P has E = E_P and λ = ℓ_P
Maximum frequency - higher would create black hole
